DETAILINGREDOXABILITYSUPPORTEDPTSNPTINCATALYSTSFORCO2ASSISTEDPDH DOOGHE L 1 Introduction 2 Materials & methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Support preparation 2.1.2 Catalyst synthesis 2.2 Basic characterization 2.3 In situ Quick XAS 2.3.1 Experimental setup 2.3.2 Sequence 1 2.3.3 Sequence 2 2.3.4 XANES data analysis 2.3.5 MEXAS data analysis 2.3.6 EXAFS data analysis 2.4 Temporal Analysis of Products (TAP) 2.4.1 Experimental procedure 2.4.2 TAP data analysis 3 Results I: Pt:Sn structural characterization under redox conditions 3.1 XANES analysis 3.1.1 H2-TPR (sequence 1) yields a Pt-Sn alloy 3.1.2 CO2-TPO (sequence 1) segregates the Pt-Sn alloy 3.1.3 Isothermal H2/O2 redox cycles (sequence 1) increase the Sn content of the Pt-Sn alloy 3.1.4 Reverse Water-Gas Shift reaction (“RWGS”, sequence 2) induces minor changes in regular XANES 3.1.5 Isothermal CO2-oxidation (“IsoOx”, sequence 2) yields incomplete oxidation of the Pt-Sn alloy 3.2 Modulation Excitation with H2/CO2 cycles 3.3 EXAFS analysis 3.4 Temporal Analysis of Products 3.4.1 A reduced Pt-Sn surface consumes a negligible amount of CO2 pulses 3.4.2 A spent Pt-Sn surface consumes CO2 pulses 3.4.3 CO2-H2 pump–probe experiments exclude lattice oxygen involvement 4 Results II: Pt:In structural characterization under redox conditions 4.1 XANES analysis 4.1.1 H2-TPR (sequence 1) yields a Pt-In alloy 4.1.2 CO2-TPO segregates the Pt-In alloy 4.1.3 Isothermal H2/O2 redox cycles (sequence 1) maintains the in content of the Pt-In alloy 4.1.4 Reverse Water-Gas Shift reaction (RWGS, sequence 2) maintains the alloy in a mildly oxidized state 4.1.5 Isothermal CO2-oxidation (“IsoOx”, sequence 2) segregates the Pt-In alloy 4.2 Modulation Excitation with H2/CO2 cycles 4.3 EXAFS analysis 5 Conclusions 6 Associated Graphical abstract Alloying Pt with In or Sn crucially improves Pt-based propane dehydrogenation (PDH) catalysts. CO2-assisted PDH (CO2-PDH) offers further benefits through H2 and carbon oxidation, but adds a complex interplay between alloy oxidation, nanoparticle (NP) sintering and carbon formation. Developing Pt-based CO2-PDH catalysts requires deconvoluting the hereto unidentified alloy properties and reaction mechanisms. This is studied through in situ Quick X-ray Absorption Spectroscopy and Temporal Analysis of Products on Pt:Sn/MgAl2O4 (Pt:Sn) and Pt:In/MgAl2O4 (Pt:In) catalysts (3 wt% Pt and 3 wt% In/Sn). Pure CO2 segregates the alloys while cofeeding CO2 and H2 largely retains Pt3Sn and Pt13In9 phases. On Pt:Sn, CO2 mainly interacts with H2 and carbon deposits via a Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism. Regenerative H2/O2 cycles cause Sn enrichment with a constant 0.9 nm NP size. Pt:In retained the Pt13In9 phase but showed NP growth from 0.8 to 2.1 nm, with greater susceptibility to alloy segregation and vaporization of In. This highlights Pt:Sn as more promising catalyst. Keywords CO2-PDH Redox properties Platinum-indium alloy Platinum-tin alloy Supported metal catalyst MEXAS TAP Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Propylene is the second most important building block in the chemical industry.[1–3] Over the past decade, the demand for propylene has surpassed its production, leading to a growing “propylene gap”.[4] On-purpose production of propylene crucially contributes to the closure of this gap.[1,2,5,6] A leading example of such on-purpose technique is the dehydrogenation of propane (PDH).[7–10] In this process, hydrogen gas is extracted from propane, typically over a supported Pt catalyst.[2,7,11–13] However, making the PDH process future-proof still encompasses challenges that need to be tackled.[1,5,6] Due to the high reaction endothermicity, high process temperatures are required to increase the equilibrium conversion of propane (800–1100 K).[2,6,7,11,12] This leads to unwanted side reactions, decreasing the propylene selectivity and resulting in concomitant carbon formation on the catalyst surface. Consequentially, frequent catalyst regeneration is needed. The latter typically involves burning off the accumulated carbon in O2, followed by a reduction in H2 to regenerate the metallic state of the Pt catalyst.[2,7,11,12]. One of the tools at hand to tackle these challenges is the addition of a second metal to Pt, acting as promoter. Upon reduction, these two metals may form bimetallic alloyed nanoparticles (NPs) on the support surface. Through a combination of electronic and geometric effects, this alloying suppresses sintering of the Pt-based NPs and increases the product selectivity. Concomitantly, carbon formation on the catalyst surface is diminished.[7,11,12,14] Two of the most commonly studied promoters for PDH are Sn[15–20] and In[21–24]. Another strategy to overcome the PDH challenges is the addition of an oxidant to the process (e.g. via co-feeding). This enables oxidation of the formed H2, which through Le Chatelier’s principle will result in an increase of the propane equilibrium conversion.[8] Consequentially, lower process temperatures are needed to reach a certain conversion, thereby increasing the propylene selectivity.[25,26] Moreover, accumulated carbon can be gasified off the surface through oxidation, cutting down on the need for catalyst regeneration. As oxidants, O2 and CO2 have been commonly researched.[8,27] Because O2 oxidizes the hydrocarbons present and entails stringent process safety measures due to high exothermicity[27], the use of CO2 (“CO2-assisted PDH” or CO2-PDH) has been found to show greater potential. In addition, the utilization of CO2 is an important strategy in the mitigation of climate change.[28,29]. The mechanism by which the CO2-PDH reaction takes place over bimetallic Pt-Sn and Pt-In catalysts remains to be established, mostly because the presence of CO2 induces changes in the catalyst structure that are not yet completely understood.[5,6] For example, sequential treatments of dehydrogenation/O2 or H2/O2 can increase the Sn content of the Pt-Sn alloy.[17,18] On a model Pt13In9 catalyst, similar H2/O2 redox cycling leads to concomitant alloying/segregation of Pt-In.[21,22] Prior work from our group[17] showed that also soft oxidants such as CO2 can affect the alloy integrity. For a Pt-Sn system, oxidation of Sn by CO2 caused segregation of Sn from the alloy, forming SnO2. In the same work, it was reasoned that in simultaneous presence of CO2 and H2 (i.e. Reverse Water-Gas Shift or RWGS), an increased ratio of CO2 vs. H2 concentrations could facilitate Pt-Sn alloy segregation. Finally, neither a direct mechanism (Langmuir-Hinshelwood, LH) nor a redox mechanism (Mars-van Krevelen, MvK) could be excluded as possible pathway for CO2-PDH.[17] It was therefore suggested that CO2-PDH proceeds through a combination of both mechanisms on Pt-Sn. In contrast, In has a higher affinity for CO2 oxidation (SI, Figure S1 ) than Sn. Although it has been reported that In with bulk properties cannot be oxidized by CO2 [30], oxidation of In in the form of supported NPs could be possible under influence of metal-support interactions.[31,32]. The objective of this study is to comprehensively explore the structural dynamics of Pt-Sn and Pt-In catalysts under various oxidative and reductive conditions, both separately and simultaneously. For this purpose, samples with a higher (In or Sn)/Pt atomic ratio of 1.7/1 were utilized, in contrast to prior investigations which employed a lower Sn/Pt ratio of 1/3.[17] The rationale for selecting a higher loading includes the anticipated enhancement in PDH activity, rendering these samples more representative of their practical application.[18,19] Additionally, the higher ratio aims to mitigate previously observed difficulties in alloy formation between Pt and Sn associated with the lower 1/3 ratio, which were attributed to the increased spatial separation between the elements. By employing a higher 1.7/1 ratio, preservation of the alloyed state is promoted. As support, an MgAl2O4 spinel similar to the “HSA (high surface area)” support from prior work[17] is used, because of its thermal and chemical stability, high porosity, and balanced acid-base properties.[15,33–35] In situ Quick X-ray Absorption Spectroscopy (QXAS) is used to assess the local environment of Pt and Sn/In during exposure to different reductive and/or oxidative atmospheres. Harsh H2/O2 redox environments pertain to a typical catalyst regeneration regime, while softer H2/CO2 environments emulate conditions as would occur under CO2-PDH. A first experimental application of such imposed H2/CO2 environment is the RWGS reaction. A second is a concentration-based Modulation Excitation QXAS (MEXAS) experiment with H2 and CO2. When coupled with Phase-Sensitive Detection (PSD), MEXAS allows to identify and quantify the active species in a possible redox process.[36–40] Complementary, Temporal Analysis of Products (TAP)[41] is used to study the interaction of the alloy surface with H2 and CO2. The combined utilization of MEXAS and TAP allows to elucidate the dominant mechanism governing CO2-PDH, whether via Langmuir-Hinshelwood (LH) or Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) pathways. In summary, this work aims to address following questions in view of assessing and comparing the potential of Pt-Sn and Pt-In systems for CO2-PDH: • What is the influence of different redox conditions (H2/O2 and H2/CO2) upon the size, composition and stability of supported Pt-based alloys? • Can this understanding produce/exclude a CO2-PDH reaction mechanism? • Does the type of promoter (Sn vs. In) play a role? Answering these questions will contribute to catalyst development for CO2-PDH, as well as to further advancements in other fields of the chemical industry that are rooted on bimetallic Pt-based catalysts. Important examples are the production of chemical building blocks[1,13], hydrogen[14], syngas[42], fuel cells[43,44] and the upgrading of (petro)chemical feedstock[2,13,14] through hydrogenation reactions[13], reforming reactions[45], CH4 conversion processes[14] and RWGS. 2 Materials & methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Support preparation The MgAl2O4 support was synthesized as described in prior work.[17,35,46] Co-precipitation of Mg(NO3)2·6H2O and Al(NO3)3·9H2O with an Mg/Al molar ratio of 1/2 was performed, with NH4OH (ACS reagent, 28.0–30.0 % NH3 basis) as precipitation agent, while maintaining a pH of 10 at 333 K. The precipitate was filtered and dried in air at 393 K for 24 h, followed by calcination in air at 923 K for 5 h, with a ramp rate of 2 K/min. 2.1.2 Catalyst synthesis Three catalysts were prepared by incipient wetness (co–)impregnation: Pt/MgAl2O4 (3 wt% Pt), Pt:In/MgAl2O4 (3 wt% Pt, 3 wt% In) and Pt:Sn/MgAl2O4 (3 wt% Pt, 3 wt% Sn). Precursors used were H2PtCl6·xH2O (>99.9 %, Sigma-Aldrich), In(NO3)3·xH2O (Sigma-Aldrich, 99.99 %) and SnCl2 (>99.9 %, Sigma Aldrich). The precursors were dissolved in absolute ethanol for impregnation. Impregnated materials were dried for 2 h at 393 K, followed by calcination in air for 4.5 h at 903 K, yielding the “As Prepared” samples. The Pt:In/MgAl2O4 and Pt:Sn/MgAl2O4 shall henceforth be labelled as Pt:In and Pt:Sn. The monometallic Pt/MgAl2O4 catalyst was prepared to serve as a reference for QXAS. Commercial PtO2 was purchased as oxide reference for QXAS (Sigma-Aldrich, 99.99 %). 2.2 Basic characterization N2-physisorption was used to determine the BET specific surface area and porosity. Samples were degassed with N2 for 3 h at 413 K prior to N2-sorption at 77 K (Micromeritics, Tristar). The BET specific surface area was determined through a 5-point method. SEM-EDX was performed on the support to obtain an estimate of the molar ratio of Mg and Al. A SEM JEOL JSM 5400 equipped with an INCA x-act extension (Oxford Instruments) for Energy Dispersive X-ray (EDX) measurements was used. Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectroscopy (ICP-OES, IRIS intrepid II XSP from Thermo Scientific) was used to determine the bulk compositions of the catalysts. All samples were mineralized by peroxide fusion. N2-physisorption results for the support and the catalysts are listed in Table 1 , together with SEM-EDX compositional results for the MgAl2O4 support and ICP values for the Pt:In and Pt:Sn catalysts. The catalysts have a slightly lower BET specific surface area and porosity than the bare support. An average NP size was derived via Dark-Field Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy (DF-STEM, SI Figure S29 ). Samples were deposited onto a lacey carbon film on a Cu grid support. A JEOL JEM-2200FS with Schottky-type field-emission gun (Cs corrected) at 200 kV was used. 2.3 In situ Quick XAS 2.3.1 Experimental setup Synchrotron-basedin situQXAS experiments were conducted at the ROCK beamline of the 2.75 GeV SOLEIL light source (Saint-Aubin, France). Measurements were performed in transmission at the Pt LIII-edge (11563.7 eV), In K-edge (27939.9 eV) and Sn K-edge (29200.1 eV). Edges of Pt and In/Sn were measured in parallel using either a Si(111) or Si(220) oscillating monochromator, by means of a macro for fast edge and detector switching.[47,48] The 2 Hz oscillation frequency of the monochromators enabled collection of multiple spectra in small time steps, of which only scans from the forward oscillation movement were used for analysis. The X-ray intensities were measured using ionization chambers, filled with pure N2 for the Pt edge energy and with 33 % N2 and 67 % Ar for the Sn and In K edge energies. The fast edge switching allowed for quasi-simultaneous acquisition of spectra at both the edges of Pt and the promoter, with a relatively short time delay (∼60 s) for the monochromator switch.[47,48] For steady-state conditions, e.g. under inert gas at room temperature (RT), scans were recorded for several minutes: first at the Pt edge, then at the promoter edge. For temperature programmed or modulated treatments, faster edge switching was applied (e.g. 20 s). Approximately 5 mg of “As Prepared” sample was loaded in a quartz capillary reactor (1.8 mm outer diameter and 50 µm wall thickness). The sample was kept in place by means of quartz wool plugs. The capillary reactor was mounted in a frame that was connected to gas feed lines through Swagelok fittings. The gas flows were set by means of calibrated mass flow controllers. A total gas flow of 10 Nml/min was maintained, resulting in a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 264 h−1. For the temperature programs, a calibrated external heat gun was used in conjunction to a thermocouple placed inside the catalyst bed. 2.3.2 Sequence 1 Two in situ QXAS sequences were performed, each starting with a fresh sample (“As Prepared”). The first sequence aimed to follow the reducing and oxidizing evolution (H2-TPR and CO2-TPO) of the measured element, after which the sample was reduced again in view of aging it (H2/O2 cycles). This is depicted in Fig. 1 and is further detailed as follows: 1. Ex situ recording at room temperature (RT) for EXAFS modelling of calcined catalysts.[49] This sample state is labelled “As Prepared”. 2. H2-Temperature Programmed Reduction (H2-TPR) to obtain alloyed nanoparticles (NPs). A ramp rate of 5 K/min up to 873 K with 20 min dwell time was employed, using flows of 1 Nml/min H2 and 9 Nml/min He. Spectra for EXAFS modelling were acquired after subsequent cooldown to RT in He for improved signal-to-noise ratio.[49] This sample state is labelled “After TPR”. 3. CO2-Temperature Programmed Oxidation (CO2-TPO) to observe the effect of CO2 on the alloy with increasing temperature. A ramp rate of 5 K/min up to 873 K with 20 min dwell time was employed, using flows of 5 Nml/min CO2 and 5 Nml/min He. Spectra for EXAFS modelling were acquired after subsequent cooldown to RT in He for improved signal-to-noise ratio. This sample state is labelled “After TPO”. 4. H2-TPR to regenerate the alloyed state. A ramp rate of 5 K/min up to 873 K with 10 min dwell time was employed, using flows of 1 Nml/min H2 and 9 Nml/min He. 5. Isothermal H2/O2 redox cycles to examine the effect of repeated oxidation–reduction with harsh redox conditions, representative for catalyst regeneration after a reaction. The first half-cycle consisted of 20 min flows of 1 Nml/min O2 and 9 Nml/min He. The second half-cycle consisted of 20 min flows of 1 Nml/min H2 and 9 Nml/min He. A full cycle was repeated 5 times at 873 K. 6. Isothermal H2-reduction to regain the alloyed state. Flows of 1 Nml/min H2 and 9 Nml/min He were employed for 10 min at 873 K. 7. Modulation Excitation QXAS (MEXAS) to identify a possible redox mechanism for these catalysts. Square-wave concentration modulations were applied by periodic variation of the CO2 flow, while maintaining a constant H2 flow. A total of 60 periods were imposed to the sample. Each period started with a 2/1 H2/CO2 ratio (2 Nml/min H2, 1 Nml/min CO2 and 7 Nml/min He), followed by a 2/3 H2/CO2 ratio (2 Nml/min H2, 3 Nml/min CO2 and 5 Nml/min He). Based on the minute-timescale of redox events reported for Pt-Ga catalysts[50], each ratio was held for 1 min, so one full period consists of 2 min. In order to avoid pressure fluctuations during flow adjustments, the switch between the 2/1 and 2/3 ratio was conducted linearly over a 10 s period. Consequently, the square wave concentration profile would rather tend towards an isosceles trapezoid. Prior work from our group showed, however, that such deviation from a square-waveform does not affect the frequency content of the response.[51] 8. Isothermal H2-reduction to regain the alloyed state. Flows of 1 Nml/min H2 and 9 Nml/min He were employed for 10 min at 873 K. Spectra for EXAFS modelling were acquired after subsequent cooldown to RT in H2 for improved signal-to-noise ratio. This sample state is labelled “After ME”. 2.3.3 Sequence 2 A second sequence was performed, starting with a fresh sample (“As Prepared”). This sequence assessed isothermal redox environments: RWGS reactions with different H2/CO2 feed ratios, using intermediate reduction in H2 to regain the alloyed state, and eventually pure oxidation with different CO2 concentrations. This sequence is depicted in Fig. 2 and is further detailed as follows: 1. H2-TPR to obtain alloyed NPs. A ramp rate of 5 K/min up to 873 K with 20 min dwell time was employed, using flows of 1 Nml/min H2 and 9 Nml/min He. 2. RWGS at 873 K with H2/CO2 ratios of 1/1, 1/3 and 1/5 to examine the effect of CO2 vs. H2 concentration. The flow of H2 was kept constant at 1 Nml/min, while the total flow was fixed at 10 Nml/min, using He as balance. The measurement for each RWGS ratio was performed twice, as only one edge (Pt LIII or In/Sn K) was recorded per reaction run. Subsequent to each RWGS run, an intermediate isothermal reduction was employed, using 10 min flows of 1 Nml/min H2 and 9 Nml/min He to ensure an alloyed state for the subsequent experiment. 3. Isothermal CO2 oxidation at 873 K to follow the alloy integrity at reaction temperature under CO2. Two different flowrates were used to assess the effect of CO2 partial pressure and to compare with the CO2-TPO from sequence 1: first with flows of 1 Nml/min CO2 and 9 Nml/min He, secondly with 5 Nml/min CO2 and 5 Nml/min He. An intermediate isothermal reduction was employed, using 10 min flows of 1 Nml/min H2 and 9 Nml/min He to ensure an alloyed state for the subsequent experiment. 4. Isothermal H2-reduction to regain the alloyed state. Flows of 1 Nml/min H2 and 9 Nml/min He were employed for 10 min at 873 K. Spectra for EXAFS modelling were acquired after subsequent cooldown to RT in H2 for improved signal-to-noise ratio. This sample state is labelled “After IsoOx”. 2.3.4 XANES data analysis For the extraction of the raw QXAS data, an interpolation grid was used. The resulting XANES region at the Pt LIII-edge had data points every 0.3 eV up to 11600 eV, whereas the Sn/In K-edge had data points every 1.0 eV up to 27990 eV (In) or 29260 eV (Sn). All recorded spectra were energy-calibrated, averaged and normalized via the Python normalization GUI developed by Roudenko.[47] Sets of 10 time-resolved spectra were averaged to improve signal-to-noise ratio, corresponding to 5 s of experimental time. For MEXAS, this means that one period of 2 min is divided into 24 sections with a resolution of 5 s, each section containing 10 spectra. In situ XANES spectra were analysed analogously to prior work[17,46] i.e. normalized and examined based on the evolution of the white line (WL) in terms of both energy position and height (henceforth termed “intensity”).[52–54] For example, the Pt LIII-edge WL probes the excitation of Pt 2p2/3 electrons to unoccupied Pt 5d orbitals. A shift in this WL energy position towards higher values is thus attributed to an increased energy level of the Pt 5d orbital, which generally indicates the formation of a Pt-based alloy. This is also observed in other XAS studies with Pt-based alloys, including Pt-Sn and Pt-In.[55–58] When comparing WL intensities across different sample treatments, it was verified whether the NP sizes remained similar.[59–61]. 2.3.5 MEXAS data analysis MEXAS data (time-resolved) were first analysed via Multivariate Curve Resolution-Alternating Least Squares (MCR-ALS) to identify the quasi-reversible regime[62] and reveal the frequency content present.[51,63] In view of enhancing the signal-to-noise ratio for Phase-Sensitive Detection (PSD), all time-resolved spectra within the quasi-reversible regime were averaged into one period. At the first demodulation index and at a given energy E , the phase-resolved absorption coefficient μ ( E , φ PSD ) is obtained from the time-resolved absorption coefficient μ ( E , t ) via Eq. (1) [36–38,62,64] Here, φ PSD represents the demodulation phase angle, t the time, and T the modulation period. The resulting phase-resolved spectra were analysed through comparison with difference spectra.[36,51,64,65] The latter were constructed from the RT acquisitions subsequent to each treatment and from reference samples. Both MCR-ALS[66] and PSD[67] were performed in MATLAB. (1) μ ( E , φ PSD ) = 2 T ∙ ∫ 0 T μ E , t ∙ s i n 2 π T ∙ t + φ PSD d t 2.3.6 EXAFS data analysis All spectra for EXAFS analysis were recorded at RT for increased signal-to-noise ratio.[49] The cooldown proceeded either in He or H2 (Fig. 1 and Fig. 2). Combined RT EXAFS and high-temperature XANES analysis confirms that neither the cooldown process nor the gas environment (He or H2) affects the conclusions. Additional reference samples were measured ex situ at RT in view of fingerprint comparison and to determine the amplitude reduction factor (S0 2) for fitting the experimental EXAFS data. These references were: Pt-foil, Sn-foil, In-foil, PtO2, SnO2 and In2O3. S0 2 was determined by fitting the first PtO2 shell (Pt-O) with a standard Pt-O path of a PtO2 crystal. Fitting of the EXAFS data was performed in the VIPER software.[68] Errors were estimated with k1/k3 weighted fittings. The Fourier transformation of the data was performed with a Kaiser-Bessel window with a Δk of 1.5 and in a k-range with zero points closest to 3–14 Å−1 for Pt and 3.5–12 Å−1 for the promoters. Once S0 2 was determined (0.95), its value was fixed to proceed with the fitting. The fitting at the Pt-edge was done in the range from 1.2 − 3.4 Å with a minimal number of shells and parameters to yield a reasonable fit (either 1 or 2 shells, depending on the data quality). For Pt, this typically was a first neighbor O or In/Sn, related to the treatment and sample state. At larger distance, a second neighbor shell of Pt-Pt was used. Following crystal structures were used for the fits: Pt, PtO2, Pt1Sn1, Pt3In7 and Pt13In9 (SI, Table S1 ). All R factors were within 0.05. For all fits, the total number of fitted parameters was at most 2/3 of the maximum number of independent parameters, respecting the Nyquist criterion for EXAFS fitting.[69]. The NP size was estimated based on the work by Frenkel et al.[70] assuming a hemispherical cuboctahedron, analogous to previous work[17,46]. The fraction of promoter M neighbouring Pt in the Pt-M alloy ( x M ) was estimated via Eq. (2) , assuming the promoter was uniformly distributed throughout the alloy.[17,46] N Pt - M represents the coordination number of Pt with element M . This was referenced against the average NP sizes obtained from DF-STEM images (SI, Figure S29 ). (2) x M = N Pt - M N Pt - M + N Pt - P t 2.4 Temporal Analysis of Products (TAP) 2.4.1 Experimental procedure Temporal Analysis of Products (TAP) is a kinetic characterization technique developed by Gleaves et al., which combines the concepts of molecular beam scattering and relaxation methodology.[41,71] This is elaborated upon in the SI and thematic literature.[41,71–79] TAP was used to probe the interaction of CO2, H2 and C3H8 with the surface of Pt:Sn, complementary to QXAS. Experiments were performed with a TAP-3E reactor system, described by Gleaves et al..[77] The microreactor was loaded in a Thin-Zone Tap Reactor (TZTR) configuration[74], using 11 mg of catalyst between two inert quartz beds, with particle sizes of 250–300 µm and 150–200 µm, respectively. This resulted in a total amount of 6.6∙1017 atoms Pt and 1.6∙1018 atoms Sn in the reactor. The samples were pretreated through in situ H2-TPR with a ramp rate of 10 K/min to 873 K, followed by a 30 min dwell to obtain alloyed NPs. Continuous gas flows were employed at atmospheric pressure (9 Nml/min H2 and 51 Nml/min Ar). Next, the reactor was evacuated isothermally towards 2.8∙10−6 Pa at 873 K for 15 min. The acquired catalyst state (akin to “After TPR” from QXAS) was the starting point of three types of pulse experiments, all at 873 K and within the Knudsen diffusion regime (2.5∙1014 molecules/pulse): 1. State defining experiments [72] with 400 CO2/Ar (9/1) pulses on a reduced Pt:Sn sample, to assess the oxidation of alloyed Sn by CO2 in Knudsen conditions. 2. State altering experiments [72] with 240 C3H8/Ar (9/1) pulses on a reduced Pt:Sn sample, to assess the dehydrogenation activity in Knudsen conditions and to deposit carbon on the catalyst surface. This was followed by in situ state altering experiments with 240 CO2/Ar (9/1) pulses, to assess carbon oxidation by CO2. This was again followed by a second in situ state altering experiment with 120 C3H8/Ar (9/1) pulses to assess the state of the catalyst surface after the (CO2/Ar) pulses. 3. Pump-probe experiments [72] on a reduced Pt:Sn sample, using (CO2/Ar, 9/1) as pump and (H2/Ar, 9/1) as probe pulses to study the interaction mechanism between CO2 and H2 on Pt:Sn. The pump–probe time interval (Δt) was varied between 0.5 s and 5.0 s. 2.4.2 TAP data analysis The reactor outlet was recorded by means of an Extrel QC 150 quadrupole mass spectrometer. The recorded signals were processed in MATLAB.[78,80] First, offset baselines were brought back to zero through a vertical shift, based on windows across the first and last recorded datapoints for each pulse. Next, a correction was performed for overlapping fragments at all scanned AMUs, based on daily calibration experiments. This is elaborated upon in the Supporting Information. The data were analysed via the method of moments.[79] M z , i α i , c o r r (Eq. (3) ) is the z th order moment of f i α i , c o r r ( t ) . The results for the monometallic Pt sample are shown as reference in SI, Figure S3 . The Sn K-edge data are shown in SI, Figures S4-S6 . RT measurements subsequent to each treatment are gathered in SI, Figure S7 . The results of H2/CO2 MEXAS (sequence 1) are elaborated on separately. 3.1.1 H2-TPR (sequence 1) yields a Pt-Sn alloy The WL evolution at the Pt LIII-edge is representative for the formation of a Pt-Sn alloy.[55–58,81] Specifically at the end of the H2-TPR treatment, the intensity of the WL was similar to that of reduced Pt/MgAl2O4, while its energy position was 1.2 eV higher (11568.4 eV vs. 11567.2 eV, SI Figure S3 a). Comparable catalysts were studied in prior work.[17] There, the final WL position of a Pt-Sn catalyst (“Pt:Sn/HSA“) was 1 eV higher when compared to a reduced monometallic Pt catalyst. The corresponding alloy phase was Pt3Sn. Given the resembling WL position shifts in the current work, a similar average alloy phase has likely formed upon reduction. At the Sn K-edge, the WL position lowered from 29210.0 eV (1.44 intensity) to 29208.0 eV (1.17 intensity). These evolutions in WL position and intensity point to a reduction of SnO2. However, the final WL position and intensity after H2-TPR is intermediate to the ones of SnO2 and metallic Sn references. Moreover, the final WL profile matches both SnO[82] or alloyed Pt-Sn (SI Figure S4 c). Hence, although the formation of alloyed Pt-Sn is implied from the Pt LIII-edge data, the presence of some SnO cannot be excluded. The final state at the Sn K-edge can therefore be considered as a mixture of Pt-Sn alloy and SnO, the latter pointing at incomplete SnO2 reduction. 3.1.2 CO2-TPO (sequence 1) segregates the Pt-Sn alloy Loss of the Pt-Sn alloy is observed at the Pt LIII-edge through an increase in WL intensity and a position shift towards lower energies (11567.2 eV, Fig. 3 b). At the end of CO2-TPO, the Pt LIII WL reached a higher intensity (1.40) than that reached by the monometallic Pt sample (1.32) (SI, Figure S3 ). This reflects a more vacant Pt 5d orbital in the Pt:Sn sample, as compared to the monometallic Pt sample.[56] Based on the behaviour of the monometallic Pt sample, it can be assumed that Pt is not oxidized through direct interaction with CO2. Analysis of the Sn K-edge (SI, Figures S4 and S7 ) indicates an oxidation of Sn back to the “As Prepared” state. The WL returned to 29210.0 eV with a corresponding intensity increase to 1.44. The observed oxidation of Pt can therefore be ascribed to the nearby interaction between Sn and CO2, yielding SnOx species that also provide O neighbours to Pt.[17] A more detailed analysis of the Pt neighbour species is provided in the EXAFS results section, §3.3. Plotting WL intensity vs. temperature during CO2-TPO (Fig. 3 c) reveals that Sn oxidizes before Pt. This is evidenced by the earlier rise of the Sn K-edge WL compared to the Pt LIII WL. Sn first forms SnO before forming SnO2. This transition is evidenced by the relatively constant WL intensity at the Sn K-edge between 300 K and 400 K, after which the intensity begins to rise. Since SnO and Pt-Sn alloy have similar WL intensities and positions (SI, Figure S4 c), it can be assumed that Sn is in fact oxidizing to SnO at these low temperatures of 300–400 K. At the Pt LIII-edge, the WL initially goes through a dip while the WL intensity at the Sn K-edge shows a concurrent increase. This indicates a simultaneous onset of Sn oxidation (Sn K-edge) and Sn loss from the alloy (Pt LIII-edge). The oxidation appears completed at 700 K, based on the plateau reached in the WL intensities (Fig. 3 c). 3.1.3 Isothermal H2/O2 redox cycles (sequence 1) increase the Sn content of the Pt-Sn alloy The Pt LIII spectra obtained at the end of each half-cycle of the H2/O2 redox experiment are shown in Fig. 3 d, while the Sn K-edge spectra are shown in SI, Figure S4 d. The WL intensity for the O2 half-cycles shows an overall decreasing trend. This can be ascribed to a delayed reoxidation process, which in turn can have two major causes: (i) NP sintering and (ii) an increase of the average Sn content in the alloyed NPs. When assuming negligible NP sintering (§3.3), evidence for the latter can be found in the RT measurements at the end of sequence 1 (“After ME” in SI, Figure S7 a). Namely, the Pt LIII WL position increased to 11569.0 eV after the H2/O2 redox cycles and H2/CO2 modulation steps. Additional evidence is found in the evolution of the Pt LIII WL position during the H2 half-cycles, which gradually shifts upward from 11568.4 eV to 11568.7 eV (Fig. 3 d and SI, Figure S5 ). A higher average Sn content will result in less reoxidation of Pt during the O2 half-cycle, and therefore less O neighbours for Pt. The Sn K-edge maintains consistent WL profiles at the end of each half-cycle (SI, Figure S4 d), hence the state of Sn after each O2 exposure is very similar to the original Sn state. These observations suggest that a redox mechanism could be present. However, the delay in Pt reoxidation during the O2 half-cycle suggests that this only occurs to a limited extent and/or requires a larger timescale at isothermal conditions. This could be even more true when using CO2 as soft oxidant under isothermal conditions. 3.1.4 Reverse Water-Gas Shift reaction (“RWGS”, sequence 2) induces minor changes in regular XANES The H2-TPR results showed that SnO2 can be (partially) reduced, while CO2-TPO can oxidize Sn back to SnO2 (Fig. 3). In RWGS, both H2 and CO2 are present simultaneously. This reaction can be considered as a model reaction for studying the alloy stability in the context of CO2-PDH (i.e. simultaneous presence of reductive and oxidative gasses). Based on the discussion of the results presented in Fig. 3, it is anticipated that Sn atoms could participate in a redox-type mechanism during RWGS. Previous work showed that the alloyed state between Pt and Sn was maintained during RWGS with a 1/1 molar feed ratio of H2/CO2.[17] In this work, the observed changes at the Pt LIII-edge imply minor oxidation of the sample after RWGS with a 1/1 feed ratio (Fig. 4 ). The WL position remains identical to the “After TPR” state, but the WL intensity gradually increases throughout the reaction. With lower H2/CO2 feed ratios (i.e. a more oxidative environment), the increase in WL intensity tends towards slightly higher values. This implies a possible increasing (but still low) extent of oxidized Sn atoms, resulting from a possible participation in a redox mechanism. Complementary analysis of the Sn K-edge could not be performed due to an instrument error. 3.1.5 Isothermal CO2-oxidation (“IsoOx”, sequence 2) yields incomplete oxidation of the Pt-Sn alloy To further separate oxidizing from reducing effects, the alloy stability in presence of CO2 was assessed by isothermal exposure to two different concentrations of CO2 in He (10 % and 50 % CO2 in He), each for 20 min at 873 K. The results at the Pt LIII-edge are shown in Fig. 5 . For the 10 % CO2 feed, the WL intensity hardly changes, while its position is lowered by 0.6 eV (from 11568.4 eV, same as “After TPR”, towards 11567.8 eV). However, this WL position is still 0.6 eV higher than that of monometallic Pt (11567.2 eV). This points to the presence of alloyed Pt-Sn with a reduced average Sn content compared to the “After TPR” state. The effect of a higher CO2 concentration (50 % CO2 feed) is not pronounced, as only a moderately higher final WL intensity is reached after 20 min. The WL at the Sn K-edge (SI, Figure S6 ) shows minimal changes for the 10 % CO2 feed, confirming the finding that Sn did not segregate completely from the Pt-Sn alloy phase. These changes become slightly more apparent with the 50 % CO2 feed, implying a slightly larger extent of Sn segregation/oxidation. Based on the WL evolutions, the CO2-TPO treatment from sequence 1 yielded a larger extent of Sn oxidation compared to the isothermal CO2 oxidation treatment. A possible explanation for this variation could lay in the different experimental conditions and sample history. The isothermal oxidation of sequence 2 persisted for 20 min at 873 K, whereas 60 min had passed between onset and completion of Sn oxidation in the CO2-TPO experiment, see Fig. 3 c. Additionally, the sample in sequence 2 had been exposed to RWGS treatments and H2 regenerations for a total of 180 min. This may have acted as stabilizing treatment for the subsequent isothermal oxidation experiments. In contrast, the pretreatment for the CO2-TPO was a single H2-TPR experiment. To conclusively clarify this variation, additional quantitative in situ data are needed. After this IsoOx experiment, the samples were reduced for 10 min at 873 K before cooling down to RT to record the EXAFS spectra (“After IsoOx”). The WL position at the Pt LIII-edge returned to 11568.4 eV (identical to “After TPR”), indicating a reconstruction of the earlier obtained Pt-Sn alloy phase. 3.2 Modulation Excitation with H2/CO2 cycles Thus far, the in situ XANES analysis of Pt:Sn has revealed that the Pt-Sn alloy readily forms and segregates during separate reductive and oxidative treatments, when applying a temperature ramp (sequence 1). This points to the possible existence of a redox mechanism, which is however nuanced in simultaneous presence of CO2 and H2 (RWGS), where indications for a redox mechanism are minor. Nevertheless, the small changes at the Pt LIII edge do not exclude variations at the surface, which go unnoticed in the bulk XANES signal. To discern and possibly quantify the existence of such surface redox mechanism, MEXAS was performed with a constant H2 flow and periodic alteration of the CO2 flow. In combination with PSD analysis, these modulated experiments can reveal spectral changes that are not apparent in the time-resolved spectra.[65]. Phase-Sensitive Detection (PSD) was performed at the Pt LIII-edge on the 15 periods of the quasi-reversible regime, with averaging across all 15 periods to increase the signal-to-noise ratio (SI, Figure S8 ). The resulting phase-resolved spectra are shown in Fig. 6 a and still exhibit a low signal-to-noise ratio, further indicative of a minor response of the sample to the modulations. No PSD analysis could be performed at the corresponding Sn K-edge data since no quasi-steady state regime was reached for this element. To interpret the phase-resolved spectra, the spectrum at the phase angle of maximal amplitude (φ = 330°) is compared with several difference spectra, created from RT EXAFS measurements.[36,51,64,65] Reasonable resemblance is obtained with difference spectra created from a metallic Pt reference minus a state after an in situ treatment (i.e. alloyed phases). Based on the first post-edge minimum intensity, at ∼ 11570 eV, the closest match is found for a difference spectrum based on a metallic Pt reference minus the “After TPR” spectrum (Fig. 6 b). These results imply that the Pt species that respond to the modulation are undergoing a change between monometallic and alloyed Pt. The fraction of Pt atoms that actively participates in this response can be estimated by the comparison of the WL intensity of the phase-resolved spectrum at φ = 330° vs. the WL intensity of the difference spectrum (employing units from the output of the normalization Python code developed by Roudenko[47]). The amplitude of the former spectrum is 2 orders of magnitude lower, which points to only a minor active fraction of Pt atoms[36] whereas the majority of Pt atoms remains unchanged by the modulations. This corresponds with the small differences between components from MCR-ALS and the low peak intensity observed in the frequency content analysis (SI, Figure S8 ). Since the difference between a monometallic Pt state and an alloyed Pt-Sn state is quite significant in terms of NP crystallite phase transformation, a change of this nature likely originates from smaller NPs. The findings from PSD align with previous work[17], in which H2/CO2 cycles of pure H2 and pure CO2 in He were applied. There, MCR-ALS analysis revealed that the cycles induced changes in the Pt state between an alloyed Pt-Sn state on the one hand, and a mixture of monometallic and alloyed Pt on the other hand. These changes were far more pronounced than in the current work. Four arguments can be made to explain the lower response obtained in the current work. First, the amount of Sn in the current Pt:Sn sample is considerably higher than in the previous work. For the latter, only a small amount of Sn must leave the alloy through oxidation in order to attain an observable difference in Pt LIII-edge (i.e. alloyed vs. monometallic state). Secondly, there is a constant presence of H2 in the current modulations, making the modulations less extreme than in the previous work. This can help to maintain the integrity of the Pt-Sn alloy. Thirdly, the current RWGS experiments showed that the WL needed significant time to stabilize with more balanced H2/CO2 feed ratios. Fourth, the current sample proves to be more stable. Indeed, the isothermal CO2 oxidation did not completely segregate the alloy after a 20 min exposure, while 70 % of alloyed Pt got segregated within 1 min for the sample with lower Sn content.[17]. In brief, the current modulations do not support the implication of a redox mechanism for Pt:Sn, as inferred from XANES analysis. When comparing the XANES results for CO2-TPO and isothermal CO2 oxidation, it is expected that modulations with a larger variation of the H2/CO2 ratio could lead to changes that are sufficiently large to be observable through PSD. If the Pt:Sn sample is employed in experiments with similar conditions as the current ME experiments, including CO2-PDH conditions, it can be assumed that the alloyed Pt-Sn state will be maintained. 3.3 EXAFS analysis The fitting results for all the states of the Pt:Sn sample are presented in Table 2 for the Pt LIII-edge, while the Sn K-edge results are listed in SI, Table S3 . The R-space figures and fits are shown in Figure S10 for Pt LIII and in Figure S11 for Sn K. The k-space figures for Pt LIII are shown in Figure S12 and for Sn K in Figure S13 . An average Pt-Sn alloy phase can be identified from the EXAFS results by considering the fraction of Sn neighbouring Pt (xSn, Eq. (2) ). The xSn from the current EXAFS analysis is compared with the xSn of thermodynamically stable reference crystals, for which xSn is obtained through fitted coordination numbers (N) (SI, Table S4 ). The experimental xSn increased from 45.3 % to 65.6 % throughout experimental sequence 1, placing the corresponding average alloy phase in-between Pt3Sn and Pt1Sn1. As the sequence proceeds, a gradual though incomplete shift towards Pt1Sn1 takes place. These results are consistent with XANES analysis, where a Pt3Sn phase was suggested for the “After TPR” state, and where a relatively more Sn-rich alloy was observed at the end of the sequence (“After ME” vs. “After TPO”). Wang et al. performed DFT calculations[83] for (near-) surface alloys on small Pt-Sn clusters. Given the small NPs in this work (∼30 atoms), a considerable part of the XAS signal will stem from metal atoms residing at or near a NP surface, allowing for a comparison between these EXAFS results and the calculations of Wang et al. These authors showed that Pt3Sn is thermodynamically the most stable phase at the outermost layers of a NP, aligning with the current analysis. Furthermore, these authors showed that alloy stoichiometries intermediate to the Pt3Sn and Pt1Sn1 reference crystals considered here, such as Pt11Sn5 and Pt10Sn6, are thermodynamically less stable than Pt3Sn yet still thermodynamically favourable. The (incomplete) shift from Pt3Sn towards Pt1Sn1 throughout the current experimental sequence could have a kinetic instead of thermodynamic origin. Finally, Wang et al. report that more Sn-enriched phases (e.g. Pt2Sn3 or PtSn2) are thermodynamically unfavourable, further aligning with the current EXAFS analysis. No indication of sintering of the Pt:Sn sample was found, as the average NP size remains constant around 0.9 nm (approximately 30 atoms). Also, the total coordination number (NTot) remains constant at 6. These results validate the assumption of negligible NP sintering made during XANES analysis. A Sn enrichment in the Pt-Sn NPs can be reconciled with a constant average NP size provided that both Pt and Sn exhibit mobility on the support surface. Such mobility is anticipated from the typical melting point depression observed in NPs compared to their bulk counterparts. The Hüttig temperature (related to the mobility of atoms around defects, e.g. at a NP surface) and the Tammann temperature (related to the mobility of bulk atoms) of both elements can therefore drop below the temperature of the experimental treatments (873 K).[84] Mobility of supported Pt is also observed in literature as Pt redispersion in presence of Sn. Examples are described in the works of Pham[85] and Iglesias-Juez[18]. XANES analysis of the CO2-TPO experiment suggested a more oxidized state of Pt when compared to the “After TPR” state. EXAFS analysis at the Pt LIII-edge of the “After TPO” state indeed yields some O neighbours for Pt. Similar to the findings of prior work[17], these O neighbours could stem from Sn that segregated upon oxidation by CO2. Especially in small NPs, O neighbours could be associated to Pt via e.g. shared Sn-O-Pt bonds. EXAFS analysis from this and prior work[17,46] allows for a comparison of the extent of Pt oxidation (NPt-O) and NP size. These results point to the same phenomenon: NPt-O increases with decreasing NP size. For small NPs, it could thus be argued that Sn assists in the oxidation of Pt under CO2 atmosphere.[17,46]. At the Sn K-edge, the fits of the Sn-O paths confirm the catalyst states as found from the fits at the Pt LIII-edge (SI, Table S3 & Figure S11 ). Namely, Sn underwent complete oxidation back to its original state after CO2-TPO, in line with XANES analysis. These fits were not performed for sample states in which reduced Sn is expected: “After TPR” and “After IsoOx”. This because the Sn-O, Sn-Sn and Sn-Pt neighbours all appear in the same region between 2–3 Å (not phase-corrected). Moreover, these two sample states yielded insufficient signal-to-noise ratio for conclusive fitting. Only for the “After ME” state, a Sn-Pt path could be fitted alongside an Sn-O path at the Sn K-edge, based on the strong peak appearing at 2.7 Å in the EXAFS fitting at the Pt LIII-edge (Table 3 and SI, Figure S10 , not phase-corrected). Since the appearance of this peak coincides with an increased Sn content in the alloy for the “After ME” state, this peak could be attributed to Sn-Pt neighbours. 3.4 Temporal Analysis of Products 3.4.1 A reduced Pt-Sn surface consumes a negligible amount of CO2 pulses H2-TPR QXAS measurements showed that Pt:Sn samples form alloyed Pt-Sn NPs upon reduction, while XANES analysis of CO2-TPO showed that Sn from alloyed Pt:Sn NPs can be oxidized by CO2 at 873 K. This leaves a redox mechanism as one of the possible reaction mechanisms through which CO2-assisted PDH proceeds on the Pt:Sn sample, as postulated in previous work.[17] However, PSD analysis on H2/CO2 redox MEXAS experiments did not detect redox behaviour for Pt:Sn under the applied conditions. TAP provides a complementary approach to discern the presence of a possible redox mechanism by providing information on the surface interaction between the Pt-Sn alloy and the gas environment. Since TAP experiments were performed in the Knudsen mass transport regime, a separate assessment of the oxidizing potential of CO2 in Knudsen conditions is required. This allows to make the distinction between CO formed in the oxidation of the Pt:Sn surface and CO formed in other processes during Knudsen experiments. A pulse train of 400 pulses (2.5∙1014 molecules per pulse) of (9/1 CO2/Ar) was sent over 11 mg of reduced Pt:Sn sample. The averaged pulse responses are shown in Fig. 7 a, while the individual ones can be found in SI, Figure S14 . In Fig. 7 a, the tail of the CO2 response is broader compared to the tail of the Ar response, indicative of interaction between CO2 and the catalyst surface. The presence of a CO response suggests that this interaction could be an oxidation of surface metal (Sn) by CO2, even though the amplitude of this CO response is low. Still, when the same experiment is repeated over a fully inert quartz bed, no CO formation nor CO2 conversion is observed. In this interaction, the average CO2 conversion per pulse drops from 9 % to 2 % across the 400 pulses (inset of Fig. 7 a). When assuming that Sn is oxidized to SnO according to Eq. (9) , the oxidized fraction of Sn can be estimated from the amount of CO formed. The initial CO2 conversion of 9 % per pulse corresponds to the formation of 2.2∙10−11 mol CO and concomitant SnO per pulse. This is negligible compared to the total of 2.7∙10−6 mol Sn present in the reactor, confirming the “state defining” character of the experiment. 3.4.2 A spent Pt-Sn surface consumes CO2 pulses The interaction between CO2 and carbon depositions on the catalyst surface was also examined. A first pulse train of 240 pulses with a (9/1) C3H8/Ar ratio served to deposit carbon on the pre-reduced surface. This was followed by surface regeneration with 240 pulses of (9/1) CO2/Ar. After regeneration, again 240 pulses of (9/1) C3H8/Ar were sent. Individual pulse responses are shown in SI, Figures S15-S17 . During the first pulse train of C3H8/Ar, the selectivity towards C3H6 rises and the C3H8 conversion drops with increasing pulse number (Fig. 8 ). A switch is observed from the formation of mainly H2, and C2′s towards the formation of mainly H2 and C3H6 (SI, Figure S16 ). During the subsequent surface regeneration with CO2 pulses, consumption of CO2 and concomitant formation of CO are observed (Fig. 8 b). The magnitude of CO2 consumption is such that it cannot arise from mere lattice oxygen involvement, as represented by Eq. (9) , since the CO2 consumption of a freshly reduced Pt-Sn surface is one order of magnitude lower in Knudsen conditions (maximum 9 % CO2 conversion per pulse, Eq. (9) and Fig. 7 a). The CO2 conversion is hence associated with the oxidation of carbon (Eq. (10) or (11) ). Based on the minor involvement of lattice oxygen, the high CO2 conversion rather implies a direct interaction with surface carbon on the Pt-Sn surface, as presented in Eq. (11) . (9) Sn + CO 2 ⇌ S n O + C O (10) SnO + C ⇌ S n + C O (11) C + CO 2 ⇌ 2 C O In the second pulse train of C3H8 (Fig. 8 and SI Figure S17 ), the initial C3H8 conversion is restored, confirming the − at least partial − removal of surface carbon. Again, the C3H8 conversion drops and the C3H6 selectivity rises with increasing pulse number, albeit faster compared to the first C3H8 pulse train, implying that not all surface carbon had been removed by CO2. This coincides with the CO2 conversion not reaching 0 % after 240 pulses (Fig. 7 b). 3.4.3 CO2-H2 pump–probe experiments exclude lattice oxygen involvement To study the interaction of CO2 and H2 with the Pt:Sn surface in Knudsen conditions, CO2-H2 pump–probe experiments were performed with time intervals (Δt) from 0.5 s to 5.0 s. During the H2 probe, the formation of H2O and CO is anticipated through the RWGS reaction.[17,42,86,87] The CO pulse responses during the H2 probe are shown in Fig. 9 , along with the calculated CO yields. The H2O response is shown in SI Figure S18 . A dependency is observed between the value of Δt and the signal intensity of the produced CO and H2O. With increasing Δt, the intensity of the signal of both products drops, associated with decreasing CO and H2O yields. This indicates that the interaction between CO2 and H2 proceeds predominantly through adsorbed species in a direct mechanism, rather than through lattice oxygen in a redox mechanism. If the dominant interaction pathway would involve the participation of (near-surface) lattice oxygen, no such dependency on Δt would be observed.[87–90] This finding agrees with the results from PSD analysis on the H2/CO2 MEXAS experiments with Pt:Sn (§3.2). The latter showed that almost the entire Pt-Sn alloy is retained and thus not involved in the imposed H2/CO2 redox modulations. Combining in situ XANES with TAP reveals that the Pt-Sn nanoparticles are retained in their alloyed form, and this during the interaction between H2 and CO2, as well as during the interaction between CO2 and surface carbon. Although a true CO2-PDH reaction encompasses extra complexity with more gasses being present simultaneously (C3H8, H2 and CO2, CO, C2′s, etc.), it is likely that the Pt-Sn structure present is similar to what is observed here under redox conditions, as the interaction with H2 and CO2 are a basic part of CO2-PDH. 4 Results II: Pt:In structural characterization under redox conditions For the Pt:In analysis, it should be considered that In got vaporized out of the sample during the in situ QXAS experiments. Upon conclusion of the experiments, a yellow deposition (In2O3) was found on the reactor walls downstream of the gas flow (SI, Figure S28 ). Other authors made the same observations during high temperature experiments.[91] This volatility of In impeded the execution of TAP experiments, hence not included in this work. 4.1 XANES analysis The XANES results for the Pt LIII-edge are shown in Fig. 10 , during H2-TPR (Fig. 10 a), CO2-TPO (Fig. 10 b-c), and isothermal H2/O2-redox cycles (Fig. 10 d). In K-edge data are shown in SI, Figure S19-S21 . RT measurements subsequent to each treatment are shown in SI, Figure S22 . The results for the monometallic Pt sample are shown as reference in SI, Figure S3 . The results of H2/CO2 MEXAS from sequence 1 are elaborated on separately. 4.1.1 H2-TPR (sequence 1) yields a Pt-In alloy The XANES evolution at the Pt LIII-edge during H2-TPR (Fig. 10 a) yields a final WL position for the “After TPR” state that is 1.2 eV higher than that of monometallic Pt (11568.4 eV vs. 11567.2 eV), confirming the formation of a Pt-In alloy.[55–58] A fingerprint comparison can be made with the work of Filez et al..[22] There, the WL position was 11567.6 eV for monometallic Pt, 11568.8 eV for Pt3In, and 11570.0 eV for Pt13In9. The relative WL positions of Pt:In and monometallic Pt in the current work therefore indicate that the average In content in the obtained alloy should be similar to that of Pt3In. At the In K-edge ( Figure S19 a), the WL position decreased from 27950.0 eV (1.26 intensity) to 27949.2 eV (1.14 intensity). Both changes in position and intensity point to In2O3 reduction. However, comparing the final WL position of the “After TPR” state with that of the In-foil reference suggests incomplete reduction of In (SI, Figure S22 b). Similar findings were made for Sn. 4.1.2 CO2-TPO segregates the Pt-In alloy Loss of the Pt-In alloy is observed during CO2-TPO. At the Pt LIII-edge, the WL intensity increases, and the energy position lowers towards that of the reduced monometallic Pt sample (11567.2 eV) (Fig. 10 b). This implies that In has segregated from the Pt-In alloy, likely upon oxidation to In2O3. Oxidation of In from the alloyed NPs is in contrast with what is expected for In with bulk-like properties. Namely, the Ellingham diagram shows that oxidation of bulk In by CO2 is thermodynamically unfavourable (SI, Figure S1 ).[30] A final WL intensity of 1.50 was reached at the Pt LIII-edge, higher than the one reached for monometallic Pt upon CO2-TPO (1.32). This is similar to the Pt:Sn sample and implies an oxidized state of Pt, arising from O-In neighbours.[56] The In K-edge data support these findings. Complete oxidation of In to the “As Prepared” state upon CO2-TPO is observed (SI, Figure S1 9b & Figure S22 b). The WL energy position shifted back to 27950.0 eV with a concomitant increase in intensity to its original value of 1.25. A more detailed analysis of Pt neighbouring species is provided in the EXAFS results section (§4.3). Analogous to Pt:Sn, plotting the WL intensity vs. temperature (Fig. 10 c) reveals that In oxidizes prior to Pt, based on the earlier rise of the In K-edge WL intensity compared to that of the Pt LIII-edge. At the In K-edge, a steep slope of the WL intensity is noted, indicating that a major fraction of In is promptly oxidized at low temperatures. This slope is steeper compared to that of the Sn K-edge (Fig. 3 c), demonstrating that supported In atoms are more easily oxidized than Sn atoms. A dip of the Pt LIII-edge is not explicitly visible in Fig. 10 c. For Pt:Sn, a dip in Pt LIII-edge WL intensity coincided with a rising onset in Sn K-edge, leading to the conclusion of simultaneous Sn oxidation and segregation from the alloy. The ease of In oxidation in Pt:In may imply that the same development occurs in this sample, but with faster kinetics compared to Pt: Sn (Fig. 10 c), making a concomitant dip in Pt LIII go unnoticed. 4.1.3 Isothermal H2/O2 redox cycles (sequence 1) maintains the in content of the Pt-In alloy The nearly constant profile for the Pt LIII-edge at the end of each H2 half-cycle (Fig. 10 d) shows that Pt:In maintains a constant alloyed phase. Upon reduction and cooldown to RT at the end of sequence 1, the WL position for Pt:In returned to an identical position as that of the “After TPR” state (11568.4 eV). Unlike for Pt:Sn, no increase in promoter content was observed after H2/O2 and H2/CO2 cycles. The WL profiles of the O2 half-cycles remain more consistent compared to Pt:Sn, always evolving towards 11567.5 eV and a close to constant WL intensity. This points to a more completed reoxidation of the Pt:In sample at the end of each O2 half-cycle, again demonstrating the ease of In oxidation. The In K-edge WL profiles (SI, Figure S19 c) at the end of each O2 half-cycle support these findings, as they remain similar to the “As Prepared” In state across the cycles. Further, the WL profiles remain consistent during the H2 half-cycles. This supports the finding that the Pt-In alloy phase is likely not changing with the proceeding H2/O2 redox cycles, unlike what was observed for Pt:Sn. The results from these H2/O2 redox cycles hence suggest the possibility of a redox mechanism for Pt:In when using O2. In contrast to Pt:Sn, no delayed or slow reoxidation is observed within the applied timeframe, indicating that In could participate more readily in a redox mechanism when O2 is applied as oxidant. 4.1.4 Reverse Water-Gas Shift reaction (RWGS, sequence 2) maintains the alloy in a mildly oxidized state Based on the H2-TPR and CO2-TPO results, a redox mechanism could exist when Pt:In is exposed to both H2 and CO2 simultaneously. The WL evolution at the Pt LIII-edge during isothermal RWGS only partially supports this hypothesis, Fig. 11 , as these WL positions remain identical to the “After TPR” state, similar to Pt:Sn. Remark that the WL intensity initially increases steeply, albeit over a short value range, indicating that a minor fraction of In atoms initially gets segregated from the Pt-In alloy upon oxidation. After this onset, a stable regime is quickly reached, namely a reversible (e.g. redox) process in which the total In participation is minor but constant. The initial increase in WL intensity gets more pronounced with decreasing feed H2/CO2 ratio. At the 1/1 H2/CO2 feed ratio, the increase in WL intensity is more gradual for Pt:Sn, when compared to Pt:In. The latter further demonstrates the higher CO2 oxidation potential of In over Sn. The In K-edge data (SI, Figure S20 ) reveal minor evolutions of the WL during RWGS, and this for all feed ratios. This coincides with the constant regime being reached quickly after the initial (and minor) oxidation of In atoms. 4.1.5 Isothermal CO2-oxidation (“IsoOx”, sequence 2) segregates the Pt-In alloy Isothermal CO2 oxidation was performed on Pt:In to further disentangle oxidizing from reducing effects. At the Pt LIII-edge, the WL evolves to a final state similar to “After TPO”. (Fig. 12 vs. SI, Figure S22 a). This indicates that the Pt-In alloy segregates during both temperature programmed and isothermal admission of CO2, in contrast to Pt:Sn. A higher partial pressure of CO2 in the feed causes no difference compared to a lower CO2 partial pressure. Similar findings apply to the In K-edge data (SI, Figure S21 ). The IsoOx experiment again shows that In oxidizes more easily than Sn under CO2. Moreover, upon subsequent reduction and cooldown to RT, the Pt LIII-edge WL position returned to the “After TPR” state (11568.4 eV), proving that the earlier obtained Pt-In alloy phase was restored (SI, Figure S22 ). These additional observations under separate oxidative and reductive atmospheres again suggest the presence of a possible redox mechanism for Pt:In. However, as with Pt:Sn, the simultaneous presence of H2 and CO2 (RWGS) causes a rather limited participation of atoms in a redox mechanism for Pt:In. The facile oxidation of In can have adverse effects in CO2-PDH. Alloying Pt with a promoter metal is performed to suppress sintering of Pt, improve propylene selectivity and mitigate carbon formation. The oxidation of alloyed In leads to monometallic Pt behaviour, thus nullifying these beneficial effects and initiating catalyst deactivation. Moreover, In2O3 can block active Pt sites, additionally contributing to catalyst deactivation. 4.2 Modulation Excitation with H2/CO2 cycles H2-TPR, CO2-TPO and isothermal CO2 oxidation experiments suggest the possibility of a redox mechanism for Pt:In. However, RWGS results imply that when both H2 and CO2 are present only a minor fraction of atoms would participate in such redox mechanism. MEXAS with constant H2 and modulated CO2 modulations is needed to further discern the mechanism. However, reliable PSD analysis could not be performed due to two factors. First, beam loss during the modulations may have introduced optical artifacts. Secondly, vaporization of In was observed, thereby continuously changing the overall sample state throughout the experiments. Further details are provided in SI ( Figure S23 ). Likewise, TAP experiments could not be performed due to the high volatility of In. 4.3 EXAFS analysis The EXAFS fittings at the Pt LIII-edge for all the states of the Pt:In sample are presented Table 3, while the fitting results at the In K-edge are listed in SI, Table S5 . R-space and k-space results are shown in SI ( Figures S24-S27 ). In contrast to the Pt:Sn sample, indications of NP sintering are now observed for the Pt:In sample. Throughout the experimental sequence, a rise in average NP size is noted through the increased bond distances of RPt-In (from 2.65 to 2.74 Å) and RPt-Pt (from 2.72 to 2.83 Å). The total coordination number NTot increased concomitantly from 5.5 to 8.9 throughout the experiments. The average alloy phase present in the Pt:In sample can be identified by comparing the experimentally obtained fraction of In neighbouring Pt (xIn, Eq. (2) ) with xIn of reference crystals. The latter is obtained through fitted coordination numbers (SI, Table S6 ). For the Pt:In sample, xIn remained constant around 40 % (Table 3). For a set of plausible reference crystals, xIn gives: Pt3In7 (100 %), PtIn2 (100 %), Pt2In3 (72.7 %), Pt13In9 (45.4 %), Pt2In (41.6 %) and Pt3In (33.3 %). This suggests a match with Pt2In. However, the Pt2In phase is thermodynamically unstable above 823 K[92] while xIn remains quite constant for the Pt:In sample. The Pt13In9 or Pt3In phases are therefore more likely. Based on the coordination numbers (N) and bond distances (R) resulting from the EXAFS fittings, a closer match is obtained with Pt13In9 than with Pt3In, but a mix of both phases is equally possible. Moreover, the presence of these phases aligns with the work of Filez et al.[22] based on both XANES analysis and the k-space spectra. Based on ICP results (Table 1), the stoichiometrically expected alloy phase would be Pt2In3, assuming a pure alloy phase and assuming all Pt and In are taking part in the alloy formation. The loss of In through vaporization off the catalyst sample can partially explain why the phase identified through EXAFS fittings (Pt13In9) is less In-rich than the expected Pt2In3. When In is vaporised, it moves out of the incident X-ray beam and gets deposited on the walls downstream of the reactor, where the temperature is lower (SI, Figure S28 ). The total loss of In can thus be quantified based on the In K-edge step. When comparing the edge steps of the “As Prepared” and “After ME” states (Fig. 13 ), this loss comes to approximately 24 % of the In present at the start. During CO2-TPO, a nearly constant edge step is observed, as In likely re-oxidized below 500 K. During H2-TPR, the edge step drops around 780 K. XANES analysis of H2-TPR shows that a major part of In in the sample is already reduced by 780 K (Fig. 10 & Figure S19 a). Since the average alloy phase in this work remains constant, it can be argued that In is vaporized from the catalyst sample above 780 K when it is in unalloyed reduced form. Analogous analysis of the Sn K-edge steps for Pt:Sn showed no Sn loss (not shown). This volatility of In can facilitate NP sintering, which will adversely affect the CO2-PDH activity. The R-space spectra at the In K-edge (SI, Figure S25 ) disclose a minimal change in the state of In between the “After TPR”, “After IsoOx” and “After ME” states. This aligns with the constant xIn obtained from EXAFS fitting at the Pt LIII-edge. Fitting of the In K-edge EXAFS was not performed for these three states as a large part of In2O3 did not reduce, as evidenced by the R-space spectra. Moreover, the k-space data were noisy in the 6–8 Å−1 region, where Pt contributions are expected. Hence, only the first shells (In-O) of the “As Prepared” and “After TPO” states were fitted (SI, Table S5 ). This shows a close to complete oxidation of In after CO2-TPO, in line with the XANES analysis. XANES analysis of the Pt LIII-edge during CO2-TPO suggested an oxidized state of Pt, based on the high WL intensity. Some O-neighbours are indeed observed for Pt in the “After TPO” state (Table 3). A phenomenon similar to that of Pt:Sn could be at play. Filez et al.[22] demonstrated that alloyed Pt-In NPs segregate upon oxidation by O2, yielding a metallic Pt core surrounded by an In2O3 crust. If this occurs with the relatively small NPs of the current Pt:In sample, there will be a substantial fraction of In2O3 in contact with Pt atoms from the core, leading to a higher probability of shared O between Pt and In2O3. The O contribution from In2O3 can thus affect the Pt LIII-edge height via neighbouring Pt atoms.[17,46]. 5 Conclusions Alloying of Pt with Sn or In as promoter metals improves non-oxidative propane dehydrogenation (PDH) by increasing propylene selectivity, suppressing carbon formation, and mitigating nanoparticle (NP) sintering. In CO2-assisted PDH (CO2-PDH), CO2 further enhances the process by oxidizing produced H2 and deposited carbon. However, CO2 can also oxidize the promoter metal, inducing alloy segregation. This introduces a complex interplay between carbon formation, NP sintering, and the dynamic gas environment. As a result, the reaction mechanisms, NP alloy composition, size, and stability during CO2-PDH are poorly understood. To deconvolute these tangled phenomena, this study applied in situ Quick X-ray Absorption Spectroscopy (QXAS) and Temporal Analysis of Products (TAP) under gas environments that emulate CO2-PDH redox conditions. Insights were obtained into NP behaviour and the reaction mechanisms governing the interaction between CO2 and H2, and between CO2 and carbon depositions. Both Sn and In readily form alloys with Pt in pure H2. During CO2-TPO, promoter oxidation occurs, while in the simultaneous presence of H2 and CO2 (Reverse Water-Gas Shift, RWGS) the alloys are largely retained. Corresponding alloy compositions were Pt3Sn and Pt13In9. Different behaviours were noted for Sn and In. Repeated H2/O2 cycles, simulating catalyst regeneration, cause moderate Sn enrichment towards a Pt1Sn1 phase, with stable NP sizes of ∼ 0.9 nm. In contrast, the Pt13In9 alloy is maintained, but the NP size grows from ∼ 0.8 nm to ∼ 2.1 nm. Modulation-Excitation QXAS with H2/CO2 disclosed minimal alloying-dealloying through reduction–oxidation of Sn species, while TAP ruled out SnOx as a redox intermediate. Thus, CO2 dominantly interacts with H2 and deposited carbon through a direct Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism. Furthermore, In oxidizes more readily in presence of CO2 than Sn. In CO2-PDH, this will lead to a more pronounced alloy segregation for Pt:In, nullifying the beneficial effects of In promotion. NP sintering is further facilitated in Pt:In due to the volatility of non-alloyed metallic In, with a noted 24 % loss of In across all QXAS experiments. Sn hence emerges as a more promising promoter for CO2-PDH than In. 6 Associated content • Thermodynamics of Sn and In oxidation: Ellingham diagrams with O2 and CO2. • Methodology for EXAFS analysis: Crystal structures used for EXAFS fits. • Temporal Analysis of Products (TAP): elaboration on the concept of TAP and on the processing of MS data. • Results for Pt/MgAl2O4: XANES spectra at the Pt LIII-edge. • Results for Pt:Sn: XANES spectra at the Pt LIII-edge: detail of WL during H2 half-cycles of isothermal H2/O2 redox cycles. coredata.dc:description: Alloying Pt with In or Sn crucially improves Pt-based propane dehydrogenation (PDH) catalysts. CO2-assisted PDH (CO2-PDH) offers further benefits through H2 and carbon oxidation, but adds a complex interplay between alloy oxidation, nanoparticle (NP) sintering and carbon formation. Developing Pt-based CO2-PDH catalysts requires deconvoluting the hereto unidentified alloy properties and reaction mechanisms. This is studied through in situ Quick X-ray Absorption Spectroscopy and Temporal Analysis of Products on Pt:Sn/MgAl2O4 (Pt:Sn) and Pt:In/MgAl2O4 (Pt:In) catalysts (3 wt% Pt and 3 wt% In/Sn). Pure CO2 segregates the alloys while cofeeding CO2 and H2 largely retains Pt3Sn and Pt13In9 phases. On Pt:Sn, CO2 mainly interacts with H2 and carbon deposits via a Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism. Regenerative H2/O2 cycles cause Sn enrichment with a constant 0.9 nm NP size. Pt:In retained the Pt13In9 phase but showed NP growth from 0.8 to 2.1 nm, with greater susceptibility to alloy segregation and vaporization of In. This highlights Pt:Sn as more promising catalyst.
